messageBody:
Best to avoid singletons as the Junit classloader can give you problems.


I thought there was a test decorator which did upfront initialisation
for a group of tests. I've never used it but I've read about other
using it on this list.

Have a look at junit.extensions.TestSetup.

Dave

-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
Sent: 15 August 2001 16:08
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] Shared data between test methods in a testcase


Peter,

Wouldn't the easiest way be to just use a LazyInitializationAndSingleton
approach that each test case calls?

Ex.

public class TestSomething extends TestCase{

private Fluxer fluxer;

private class SingletonFluxer{
private static Fluxer fluxer;

public static Fluxer getInstanceOfFluxer(){
if (fluxer == null){
fluxer = new Fluxer();
}
return fluxer;
}
}

public TestSomething(String name){
super.name();
}

public void setUp(){
...
}

public void testCreate(){

//real check
fluxer = SingletonFluxer.getInstanceOfFluxer();
assertNotNull(fluxer);
}

public void testRead(){
assertTrue(SingletonFluxer.getInstanceOfFluxer().read().length()
==
9);
}

...

public void test...(){}

}
